attributes.title: Moral Codes and Wartime Calculus: Assessing Public Attitudes about Civilian Casualties

q1.value: Moral Codes and Wartime Calculus: Assessing Public Attitudes about Civilian Casualties

q5.value: Earlier versions of this article were presented at the 2016 International Law, International Norms, and Public Opinion conference at Princeton University, the 2016 and 2017 annual meetings of the American Political Science Association, and the 2017 Survey, Research on Attitudes Towards Killing in War conference at the London School of Economics. For their helpful comments at various stages of the project, we are especially grateful to Bryce Corrigan, Sarah Maxey, Neil Narang, Adam Levine, and Ben Valentino., We would also like to thank Kevin Arceneaux, Michael Barnett, Dona-Gene Barton, Allison Carnegie, Janina Dill, Matthew Evangelista, Miles Evers, Courtney Hillebrecht, Pablo Kalmanovitz, Joshua Kertzer, Jonathan Kirshner, Melissa Lee, Bridget Marchesi,, Alison McQueen, Lauren Prather, Jessica Price, Scott Sagan, Rachel Stein, Geoffrey Wallace, Sergio Wals, Michael Walzer, and Karen Yarhi-Milo.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: (The authors submitted the following updated response to this field on March 22, 2019.) This study investigates two puzzles. The first puzzle is whether or not civilian harm by the U.S. military affects public support. Scholars in the “strategic public” camp point to the public’s preoccupation with winning wars (Sagan and Valentino 2017; Press et al 2013; Gelpi, Feaver and Reifler 2009; Jentleson 1992) and concern for American combatant deaths (Boettcher and Cobb 2006; Eichenberg 2005; Gartner 2008; Feaver and Gelpi 2005; Mueller 1994). From this perspective, foreign civilian harm would only affects public support for war if the public believes this harm is militarily counter-productive. In contrast, the “moral public” camp points to moral (Johns and Davies forthcoming; Chilton 2015; Walsh 2015; Larson and Savych 2006) and legal (Chilton 2015; Kreps and Wallace 2015; Kreps 2014; Wallace 2013) norms against civilian killing as determinants of public support for war. The second puzzle investigates why Black Americans have opposed U.S. wars at higher levels than White Americans. On the one hand, research suggests that the race gap may be a result of strategic beliefs. Compared to White Americans, Black Americans hold “dovish” foreign policy views consistent with their Democratic partisan leaning (Ender, Rohall and Matthews 2015). As such, Black Americans may be sensitive to civilian harm on the belief that this harm undermines U.S. military effectiveness. On the other hand, researchers have suggested that ethnocentrism and acceptance of racism help explain support for war among White Americans (Green working paper; Kam and Kinder 2007). Black Americans may be sufficiently resistant to these dispositions for moral concern for the civilian victims of U.S. wars to influence their attitudes.

q16.value: (The authors submitted the following updated response to this field on March 22, 2019.) Hypothesis 1 (strategic public): The intent behind war-time civilian killing does not lower public support for conflict, except on the condition that the public believes violating the norm of noncombatant immunity imposes strategic costs on the U.S. Hypothesis 2 (tribal public): The intent behind war-time civilian killing has no impact on support for the use of force. Hypothesis 3 (moral public): Public support for the use of force decreases as civilian harm shifts from accidental to foreseeable to intentional. Hypothesis 4 (race and the strategic public): Civilian harm decreases Black American support for the use of force more than White American support because the former believe civilian harm undermines military objectives. Hypothesis 5 (race and the moral public) : Civilian harm decreases Black American support for the use of force more than White American support because the former have greater moral concern for the foreign victims of U.S. wars.

q17.value: (The authors submitted the following updated response to this field on March 22, 2019.) This study will use the survey experimental methodology to test these hypotheses. The survey experiment asks respondents to evaluate a hypothetical scenario in which the U.S. conducts airstrikes against a terrorist organization that kills civilians. The experiment will include six treatments. For the first three treatments, the killing of civilians from the U.S. airstrikes will be described as either intentional, foreseeable, or accidental. The following three treatments will stipulate the intent and describe the airstrikes as weakening the terrorist organization. I Respondents will be asked whether or not support the airstrikes and whether or not they believe the airstrikes were morally justified. To compare the attitudes among Black and White Americans, the study will sample on race.

For their helpful comments at various stages of the project, we are especially grateful to Bryce Corrigan, Sarah Maxey, Neil Narang, Adam Levine, and Ben Valentino., We would also like to thank Kevin Arceneaux, Michael Barnett, Dona-Gene Barton, Allison Carnegie, Janina Dill, Matthew Evangelista, Miles Evers, Courtney Hillebrecht, Pablo Kalmanovitz, Joshua Kertzer, Jonathan Kirshner, Melissa Lee, Bridget Marchesi,, Alison McQueen, Lauren Prather, Jessica Price, Scott Sagan, Rachel Stein, Geoffrey Wallace, Sergio Wals, Michael Walzer, and Karen Yarhi-Milo.

attributes.title: The Effect of the Argentinian Presidential Elections on Tax Morale

q1.value: The Effect of the Argentinian Presidential Elections on Tax Morale

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: It is generally understood that low tax payments cannot be fully attributed to a state’s capacities of enforcement but that policies, institutions, and social preferences partly determine tax morale. Citizens that do not trust that taxes are well spent might be less willing to pay. We build a theoretical model that expands over this idea and hypotheses that an individual’s decision to evade taxes is i) depending on the social norm and acceptability of evading taxes and ii) on the characteristics of important role models in the society, specifically heads of government. We exploit the stark difference in presidential candidates for the 2019 Argentinian elections and purposely collected experimental data to isolate the potential drivers of tax evasion. The contributions of this study are two-fold. First, this project will contribute to our understanding of tax morale by building a comprehensive theoretical model of tax evasion and testing its hypotheses with novel evidence using a natural experiment combined with experimental data to answer the research question. Second, studies so far focus on correlations between different socio-economic indicators and tax morale, and no study, to the best of our knowledge, has specifically test for changes in social norms’ relevance or role model characteristics on tax morale.

q16.value: The main contributions of this study are: 1. What is the relative importance of social norms and role models’ behavior in comparison to standard explanations of tax evasion? 2. Do public figures influence citizens’ tax evasion behavior?

q17.value: We will exploit the unanticipated nature of the election outcomes to run a simple event study style OLS regression estimating the variation in time of surveys (before and after elections) on the outcomes collected in the survey. Before the elections we will elicit respondents’ expectations of who will win the election. This will help us determine how unexpected the election outcome really is.

attributes.title: Ideological Conflict and Attitudes Toward Immigrants in the United States and Canada

q1.value: Ideological Conflict and Attitudes Toward Immigrants in the United States and Canada

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Large-scale immigration to western countries in recent decades has spurred an extensive literature examining the factors that make native-born citizens more or less likely to accept newcomers. This research is generally characterized by two main lines of reasoning. The first posits that labor market competition makes natives feel economically threatened and leads them to feel antipathy toward immigrants (eg., Dancygier and Donnelly, 2012; Mayda, 2006; Scheve and Slaughter, 2001). The second argues that antipathy toward immigrants emerges not from economic threat, but rather feelings of symbolic, or cultural, threat (eg., Citrin et al., 1997; Kalkan, Layman and Uslaner, 2009; Sniderman and Hagendoorn, 2007). On balance, the latter view has received more empirical support (see: Hainmueller and Hopkins, 2014b). In general, it has focused on how immigrants’ language abilities, race, religion, and compliance with norms shape natives’ opinions about them. The project proposed here will examine how immigrants’ political attitudes may matter. Specifically, it asks: how does an immigrant agreeing or disagreeing with a native-born citizen about politics affect the citizen’s attitude toward that immigrant? Answering this question entails, for the first time, integrating the political science literature on public opinion toward immigrants with the social psychology literature on ideological conflict. In general, people prefer those who agree with them over those who do not. Attitudinal similarity has often been shown to supersede considerations of similarity based on race, gender, and social status (Erwin, 1971; Crano, 1997; Fawcett and Markson, 2010). The “ideological conflict hypothesis” argues that similarity-liking applies to politics as well: despite conservatives’ reputation for intolerance, people across the political spectrum have been shown to be equally willing to express negative attitudes towards and even discriminate against others if they disagree with them (Brandt et al., 2014). I seek to understand how ideological conflict—and its converse, ideological similarity—between natives and immigrants affects natives’ attitudes toward immigrants in the United States and Canada.

q16.value: H1a: Among respondents who support (each of) legal abortion, gay marriage, increased welfare spending, and environmental regulation, an immigrant opposing (each of) these positions will be associated with a decrease in the probability of the immigrant being selected for permanent residency or citizenship. H1b: Among respondents who support legal abortion, gay marriage, increased welfare spending, and environmental regulation, an immigrant also supporting these positions is associated with an increase in the probability of the immigrant being selected for permanent residency or citizenship. H2a: Among respondents who oppose legal abortion, gay marriage, increased welfare spending, and environmental regulation, an immigrant supporting these positions is associated with a decrease in the probability of the immigrant being selected for permanent residency or citizenship. H2b: Among respondents who oppose legal abortion, gay marriage, increased welfare spending, and environmental regulation, an immigrant also opposing these positions is associated with an increase in the probability of the immigrant being selected for permanent residency or citizenship. H3: Among both supporters and opponents of legal abortion, gay marriage, increased welfare spending, and environmental regulation, the negative effect of an immigrant disagreeing with them on these issues is greater than the positive effect of an immigrant disagreeing with them on these issues. H4: The negative effect of disagreement is greater among opponents of legal abortion, gay marriage, increased welfare spending, and environmental regulation than among supporters. H5a: An immigrant sharing the party identification of a respondent is associated with an increase in the probability that the immigrant is selected for permanent residency or citizenship. H5b: An immigrant not sharing the party identification of a respondent is associated with a decrease in the probability that the immigrant is selected for permanent residency or citizenship. Further exploratory hypotheses of the study are articulated below: H6: An immigrant disagreeing with a respondent on legal abortion, gay marriage, in- creased welfare spending, and environmental regulation is associated with a decrease in the probability of the immigrant being selected for permanent residency or citizenship that is greater than the decrease associated with sociodemographic attributes that have previously been shown to negatively impact immigrant evaluations, namely, being from a non-white majority country, not speaking fluent English (French), being in an unskilled labour position, not being continuously employed, and being Muslim. H7: The magnitude of the negative effects of disagreement on legal abortion, gay marriage, increased welfare spending, and environmental regulation is greater among respondents born in the United States/Canada. H8: The magnitude of the negative effects of disagreement on legal abortion, gay marriage, increased welfare spending, and environmental regulation is greater among Americans than among Canadians. H9: The magnitude of the positive effects of agreement on legal abortion, gay marriage, increased welfare spending, and environmental regulation is greater among Americans than among Canadians.

q17.value: The analysis of the conjoint data is conducted following the statistical method devel- oped by Hainmueller, Hopkins and Yamamoto (2013), which itself is grounded in the potential outcomes framework (Rubin, 1974). The estimand I aim to recover is the Av- erage Marginal Component Effect (AMCE) conditional on respondents’ pre-treatment responses to the four issue questions and the party identification question. The AMCE is the average difference in the probability of an immigrant being preferred for permanent residency/citizenship in the binary outcome question when two different values of an at- tribute are compared, where the average is calculated over all possible combinations of the other attribute values. Mathematically, the estimand can be written as: π(t1, t0, p(t)) = E[Yi(t1, Tijk[−l], Ti[−j]k) − Yi(t0, Tijk[−l], Ti[−j]k)], where Tijk[−l] denotes the vector of L-1 treatment attributes for respondent i’s jth profile in choice task k without the lth component. Inverse-probability weights (IPW) will be applied to take into consideration the fact that attributes do not have equivalent probabilities of assignment to treatment because the Muslim attribute level cannot appear with the country of origin attribute levels Mexico, Guatemala or Poland.

The “ideological conflict hypothesis” argues that similarity-liking applies to politics as well: despite conservatives’ reputation for intolerance, people across the political spectrum have been shown to be equally willing to express negative attitudes towards and even discriminate against others if they disagree with them (Brandt et al., 2014). I seek to understand how ideological conflict—and its converse, ideological similarity—between natives and immigrants affects natives’ attitudes toward immigrants in the United States and Canada.

Inverse-probability weights (IPW) will be applied to take into consideration the fact that attributes do not have equivalent probabilities of assignment to treatment because the Muslim attribute level cannot appear with the country of origin attribute levels Mexico, Guatemala or Poland.

attributes.title: Trading Justice for Punishment: A conjoint analysis of citizen’s preferences for reducing mass incarceration

q1.value: Trading Justice for Punishment: A conjoint analysis of citizen’s preferences for reducing mass incarceration

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Rates of mass incarceration in the U.S. increased dramatically over the latter half of the 20th century. Today, many Americans appear to support, at least in principle, proposals that would reduce the overall number of people behind bars. In practice, however, such support often waivers when people are asked to confront some of the more difficult realities of criminal justice, in particular, the fact that much of the growth in mass incarceration has been driven by increases in the length of sentences for serious crimes. Thus, the reforms that may have the greatest chance of winning popular support, may have the smallest impact on the prison population. Using a series of conjoint analyses, this project explores how people's support for proposals to reduce the size state prison populations, varies according to how those reductions are achieved. The goal is to understand how people value the tradeoffs between reforms that may yield big reductions in the overall number of people incarcerated but require releasing at least some people incarcerated for violent offenses, compared to other reforms that may achieve smaller reductions by decreasing the number of people incarcerated for less severe, non-violent offenses. The project explores how these dynamics change when citizens possess more information about the criminal justice system as well as when they are cued to think about the racial disparities in that system.

q16.value: - What is the average marginal causal effect (AMCE) of a proposed reduction in the percentage of people in state prisons for certain offense on support for that proposal? - How do these effects differ conditional on prior beliefs and characteristics of the individual and the additional information?

q17.value: Estimatition of AMCEs through random assignment to conjoint analyses with different prompts and information.

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

attributes.title: Are social media campaigns reaching young people? Mobilising the youth vote in the 2019 UK General Elections

q1.value: Are social media campaigns reaching young people? Mobilising the youth vote in the 2019 UK General Elections

q2.value: Florian Foos | Peter John | Asli Unan

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: In this field experiment, we work with a non-partisan organisation to test if their social media registration drive is effective at registering citizens to vote in the General Election on 12 December 2019, and if a Get-Out-The-Vote reminder 1-2 days before the election amplifies the campaigns effect on turnout. In a 2x2 factorial design, we assigned 879 postcode sectors located within 40 constituencies to four groups: one control group, one group that receives a number of voter registration videos via Instagram and Snapchat, one group that receives turnout encouragement videos via Instagram and Snapchat, and one group that received both voter registration and GOTV ads. These messages are targeted towards young people aged between 18 and 35 years, and feature social media influencers. The voter registration videos appear in postcode sectors assigned to the treatment group in the week before the voter registration deadline on 26 November. The GOTV ads appear on Tuesday and Wednesday 10 and 11 December. After the election, we will collect voter registration and turnout data at the polling station level (polling stations can perfectly be matched to postcode sectors) to test whether the campaign increased voter registration and voter turnout. The partner organisation will also attempt to provide us with data on click-throughs and engagement metrics at the postcode sector level. Finally, we plan to work with the Electoral Commission to obtain the de-identified land register matched to the marked voter register to measure voter registration and turnout at the household level. This would allow for increased statistical power and more precise estimates compared to the analysis conducted at the polling district level, however it is subject to these data being made available to us.

q16.value: 1. Voter registration ads targeted at young people have a positive effect on voter registration. 2. GOTV ads targeted at young people have a positive effect on turnout. 3. Voter registration ads targeted at young people have a positive effect on turnout. 4. Voter registration ads have a more positive effect on turnout in combination with GOTV ads.

q17.value: We use 1-tailed hypothesis tests, and reject the null hypothesis that there are no differences in registration and turnout rates if p

attributes.title: How Electoral Violence and Partisanship Affect Perceptions of Electoral Integrity: A Post-Election Survey Experiment in West Bengal

q1.value: How Electoral Violence and Partisanship Affect Perceptions of Electoral Integrity: A Post-Election Survey Experiment in West Bengal

q5.value: We thank Katja Gatterman, Mike Medeiros, Ezequiel Ocantos-Gonzalez, Gijs Schumacher, and Abbey Steele for comments on the study design.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Prior work helps us understand aggregate effects of election violence on attitudes and behavior, but has not done so experimentally, and has paid relatively little attention to the role of political parties and partisanship. Our study explores whether partisanship structures heterogeneity in responses. The omission of parties and partisanship is surprising because parties function as crucial links between political elites and citizens. We argue that partisanship may be central to explain why citizens’ responses to violence may not be uniform across individuals. Rather, the effect of violence may be shaped by partisan identities, as for example arguments on sore losers or motivated reasoning (e.g. Redlawsk 2002, Lodge and Taber 2013) would imply. We design an experiment to empirically test expectations on how election violence and partisanship shapes perceptions of electoral integrity. Theories of public-opinion updating have rarely been tested outside industrialized, advanced democracies, making it important to examine whether they apply more broadly. The study also speaks to the broader debate about the political consequences of electoral violence. The experiment will be embedded in a post-election survey in the Eastern Indian state of West Bengal, taking place after the 2019 Lok Sabha elections. The case is chosen strategically. Elections in West Bengal were marred by violence through all stages of the electoral process and continued for weeks after the voting. Violence involved clashes between party supporters, attacks organized by parties against opposing party workers and candidates, vandalism, and preventing people from voting.

q16.value: We examine the effects of election violence and partisanship on perceptions of electoral integrity. We design a survey experiment to empirically examine several hypotheses. We first assess whether respondents exposed to information about a violent event have lower perceptions of electoral integrity than those receiving neutral information about the election. Hypothesis 1: Respondents exposed to information about election violence are less likely to describe elections as free and fair than the control group. We next assess whether and how the partisan identity of the alleged perpetrator of election violence influences citizens’ responses to information about electoral violence. We examine how the win/loss status of the perpetrator influences citizens’ responses to information about electoral violence. Our rationale is that respondents will see losing candidates as “sore losers” who instigate violence to protest election outcomes. We thus expect that respondents exposed to information implicating the losing party in election violence have lower perceptions of electoral integrity than those receiving information implicating the winning party or those receiving neutral information about the election. The hypotheses below: Hypothesis 2: Respondents exposed to information identifying the losing party as the alleged perpetrator of election violence in the treatment are less likely to describe elections as free and fair than respondents in other treatment groups or the control group. We then examine how respondents’ partisanship and vote choice conditions their perceptions of the electoral process. Understanding perceptions is important for interpreting the effects of violence on attitudes, particularly if such perceptions are shaped not just by objective information about violence, but also by biases or misinformation. The literature on political violence generally assumes that citizens update their perceptions of events in objective and unbiased ways, implying that perceptions are factual interpretations of events corresponding to the rational updating model (Gerber and Green 1999). However, recent research demonstrates that citizens’ beliefs about what happens in conflict often diverge wildly from the “facts on the ground” and are subject to partisan biases (Silverman 2018). Building on work on motivated reasoning (e.g. Redlawsk 2002, Lodge and Taber 2013), we argue that partisanship structures how individuals interpret violent events, predicting that citizens disregard information that contradicts their beliefs, while accepting information confirming them. Hypothesis 3: Respondents (not) supporting the party identified as the alleged perpetrator of election violence in the treatment are (less) more likely to describe elections as free and fair than the control group.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested in a survey experiment embedded in a survey of 1080 respondents following the 2019 Lok Sabha elections in the Eastern Indian state of West Bengal. In the experiment, the respondents were randomly assigned to a control group, or one of two treatment groups, all of equal size (yielding 360 respondents per group). The assignment to the experimental condition was done at the level of the individual, while maintaining a gender split across the entire sample by blocking on gender at the PSU level. The control group received a neutral vignette without an experimental prime, simply reminding people about the past election. The two control groups, in addition to the neutral vignette, also received an experimental prime describing an incidence of electoral violence taking place during the campaign. Across the two treatment conditions the alleged political party instigating the incidence differed. The event description was fictional, but closely resembled events described in actual newspaper reporting of violent events in West Bengal before the 2019 elections, both to enhance the credibility of the prime, as well as for ethical considerations. Specifically, the vignette describes an attack against a polling agent, but randomly varies the partisan identity of the perpetrator. Similar events involving both treatments can be found in news articles. After being presented with the vignette, citizens indicate how they perceive the integrity and legitimacy of the electoral process, which is our dependent variable.

q27.value: Lokniti: Programme for Comparative Democracy; Centre for the Study of Developing Societies (CSDS); 29 Rajpur Road; Delhi 110 054 India

registration_responses.q1: How Electoral Violence and Partisanship Affect Perceptions of Electoral Integrity: A Post-Election Survey Experiment in West Bengal
registration_responses.q5: We thank Katja Gatterman, Mike Medeiros, Ezequiel Ocantos-Gonzalez, Gijs Schumacher, and Abbey Steele for comments on the study design.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: Prior work helps us understand aggregate effects of election violence on attitudes and behavior, but has not done so experimentally, and has paid relatively little attention to the role of political parties and partisanship. Our study explores whether partisanship structures heterogeneity in responses. The omission of parties and partisanship is surprising because parties function as crucial links between political elites and citizens. We argue that partisanship may be central to explain why citizens’ responses to violence may not be uniform across individuals. Rather, the effect of violence may be shaped by partisan identities, as for example arguments on sore losers or motivated reasoning (e.g. Redlawsk 2002, Lodge and Taber 2013) would imply. We design an experiment to empirically test expectations on how election violence and partisanship shapes perceptions of electoral integrity. Theories of public-opinion updating have rarely been tested outside industrialized, advanced democracies, making it important to examine whether they apply more broadly. The study also speaks to the broader debate about the political consequences of electoral violence. The experiment will be embedded in a post-election survey in the Eastern Indian state of West Bengal, taking place after the 2019 Lok Sabha elections. The case is chosen strategically. Elections in West Bengal were marred by violence through all stages of the electoral process and continued for weeks after the voting. Violence involved clashes between party supporters, attacks organized by parties against opposing party workers and candidates, vandalism, and preventing people from voting.
registration_responses.q16: We examine the effects of election violence and partisanship on perceptions of electoral integrity. We design a survey experiment to empirically examine several hypotheses. We first assess whether respondents exposed to information about a violent event have lower perceptions of electoral integrity than those receiving neutral information about the election. Hypothesis 1: Respondents exposed to information about election violence are less likely to describe elections as free and fair than the control group. We next assess whether and how the partisan identity of the alleged perpetrator of election violence influences citizens’ responses to information about electoral violence. We examine how the win/loss status of the perpetrator influences citizens’ responses to information about electoral violence. Our rationale is that respondents will see losing candidates as “sore losers” who instigate violence to protest election outcomes. We thus expect that respondents exposed to information implicating the losing party in election violence have lower perceptions of electoral integrity than those receiving information implicating the winning party or those receiving neutral information about the election. The hypotheses below: Hypothesis 2: Respondents exposed to information identifying the losing party as the alleged perpetrator of election violence in the treatment are less likely to describe elections as free and fair than respondents in other treatment groups or the control group. We then examine how respondents’ partisanship and vote choice conditions their perceptions of the electoral process. Understanding perceptions is important for interpreting the effects of violence on attitudes, particularly if such perceptions are shaped not just by objective information about violence, but also by biases or misinformation. The literature on political violence generally assumes that citizens update their perceptions of events in objective and unbiased ways, implying that perceptions are factual interpretations of events corresponding to the rational updating model (Gerber and Green 1999). However, recent research demonstrates that citizens’ beliefs about what happens in conflict often diverge wildly from the “facts on the ground” and are subject to partisan biases (Silverman 2018). Building on work on motivated reasoning (e.g. Redlawsk 2002, Lodge and Taber 2013), we argue that partisanship structures how individuals interpret violent events, predicting that citizens disregard information that contradicts their beliefs, while accepting information confirming them. Hypothesis 3: Respondents (not) supporting the party identified as the alleged perpetrator of election violence in the treatment are (less) more likely to describe elections as free and fair than the control group.

In the experiment, the respondents were randomly assigned to a control group, or one of two treatment groups, all of equal size (yielding 360 respondents per group). The control group received a neutral vignette without an experimental prime, simply reminding people about the past election. The two control groups, in addition to the neutral vignette, also received an experimental prime describing an incidence of electoral violence taking place during the campaign. Across the two treatment conditions the alleged political party instigating the incidence differed. The event description was fictional, but closely resembled events described in actual newspaper reporting of violent events in West Bengal before the 2019 elections, both to enhance the credibility of the prime, as well as for ethical considerations. Specifically, the vignette describes an attack against a polling agent, but randomly varies the partisan identity of the perpetrator. Similar events involving both treatments can be found in news articles. After being presented with the vignette, citizens indicate how they perceive the integrity and legitimacy of the electoral process, which is our dependent variable.
registration_responses.q27: Lokniti: Programme for Comparative Democracy; Centre for the Study of Developing Societies (CSDS); 29 Rajpur Road; Delhi 110 054 India

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This study is a replication of a previous study using a larger, nationally-representative sample (to address concerns about representativeness) and sensitive question survey techniques (endorsement experiments) to measure the main outcomes (to address concerns about social desirability bias). The previous study found that voters are less likely to vote for candidates with a history of violence—including coethnics—as well as coethnic candidates that use hostile, ethnicized campaign rhetoric. This study was designed to confirm whether these findings hold when tested on a nationally representative sample of the Kenyan population and when sensitive question survey techniques are used to avoid social desirability bias.

q16.value: The study is designed to test whether voters are less likely to vote for candidates with a history of violence—including coethnics—and whether they are more or less likely to vote for coethnic candidates that use hostile, ethnicized campaign rhetoric. To test these hypotheses, respondents are randomly assigned to candidate vignettes that randomly vary the respondents ethnicity and their history of violence, or the type of campaign rhetoric that they use, as detailed in the attached. They are then asked to describe their level of support for each of three policies that the candidate has proposed, as an indirect measure of their support for the candidate that avoids the pitfalls of social desirability bias associated with direct responses. The quantities of interest are the mean differences between support for the three policies proposed by candidates with vs. without a history of violence, and candidates who do or do not employ hostile ethnic rhetoric.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested by regressing the outcome of interest (combined level of support for the three policies proposed by the candidate, each measured on a five-point scale) on the treatment condition and a series of covariates that may be prognostic of support for the policies. These include urban/rural status, gender, age, education level, household income, and whether or not the respondent was previously affected by political violence. The treatment conditions for the first experiment (on the effect of violence) are as follows: 1) No stated history of violence; 2) unattributed violence; 3) offensive violence; and 4) defensive violence (see the attached for details and specific text). The treatement conditions for the second experiment are 1) no ethnic rhetoric; 2) ethnic rhetoric and no associated violence 3) ethnic rhetoric and associated violence; and 4) instigated violence but no ethnic rhetoric (again, see attached for details).

q23.value: The research was conducted under approval obtained by the partner survey research firm, Ipsos Kenya.

attributes.title: Public works programs, well-being, social cohesion and women’s empowerment: evidence from a randomized control trial in Egypt

q1.value: Public works programs, well-being, social cohesion and women’s empowerment: evidence from a randomized control trial in Egypt

q5.value: Many thanks to The Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development Agency (MSMEDA) and the World Bank Task Team for making this work possible. Funding from the Jobs MDTF and i2i TF is gratefully acknowledged. Also, thanks to the DIME team in DC and Egypt for their invaluable inputs and hard work in making this study possible.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Public work programs (PWPs) are widespread in low- and middle-income countries and have been carried out in a variety of settings, including Argentina, Ethiopia, India and South Africa, among others. Together with cash transfer programs constitute the core of many developing countries' social safety nets (Camfield, 2014). Despite the pervasiveness of PWPs across poor and developing countries, rigorous evidence about their impact and effectiveness is still scarce. The assessment of the efficiency of public work programs hinges crucially on the benefits to non-participants: either better infrastructure and/or community social services, but also non-material outcomes such as higher trust and social capital and lower violence. The PWP studied here encompasses several projects, the majority of which are specifically targeted towards women. This allows us to study the cause of low female labor force participation, a characteristic of labor markets in the MENA region. In particular, it allows us to disentangle between supply vs. demand-side explanations for the low activity rate of women. Moreover, by focusing on outcomes after the project has ended, we might be able to detect to what extend having participated to “good jobs” leads to value changes for the women participants.

q16.value: (1) What is the impact of the participation in a PWP on subjective well-being? a. Does participation in the PWP lead to an increased level of subjective well-being? b. Does participation in the PWP lead to a feeling of economic security? (2) What is the impact of a PWP on social capital, trust and violence at the community level? a. Does the randomized allocation of the ELIIP program within the community lead to grievances? b. Is there a positive effect on PWP on civic participation and engagement? c. Does PWP lead to a higher or lower level of violence or social tensions? (3) What is the impact of a PWP on female empowerment? a. Does the participation in a PWP modify attitudes towards work for women? b. Does the participation in a PWP lead to greater decision-making power for women? c. Is there any backlash in the form of increased intimate partner violence for female participants in PWP?

q17.value: For each research question, we define one or more summary indicators aggregating the response to a series a yes/no questions: • H 1.a o subjective well-being index o mental health index • H 1.b : o perception of economic conditions index (individual level) o income security index • H 2.a : o fairness of allocation process index o Perception of economic conditions index (household level) • H 2.b: o social capital index o citizenship and confidence in government index • H 2.c: o victimization index • H 3.a: o Attitude towards marriage index o Attitude towards fertility index • H 3.b: o Women decision making index o Women control over household resources index • H 4.b: o Intimate partner violence index o Violence against women index Due to randomization, the difference between treated and control units indicates the intent-to-treat effect of the program. In order to avoid possible contamination effects between treated and control units within treated villages, our main specification rests on the comparison between participating households, and between households in control villages.

q19.value: Households: 1170 units (430 control and 740 treatment). Individual workers: 2349 units (1308 treatment, 611 control, and 430 “synthetic control” from control villages). 234 villages total.

q27.value: The Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development Agency (MSMEDA)

attributes.title: Frames for Ingroup Policing during Conflict

q1.value: Frames for Ingroup Policing during Conflict

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: In situations of conflict, ingroup criticism - criticism that members of a given social group direct towards their fellow ingroup members or towards the group itself - can help prevent negative intergroup outcomes. But one factor that could determine the effectiveness of ingroup criticism is the receptiveness of others. This study tests other ingroup members’ receptiveness to two frames for criticism: A moral frame, which justifies the criticism by arguing that the criticized ingroup behavior is immoral, and a pragmatic frame, which argues that the criticized behavior is harmful to the group’s interests. These frames are tested in an experiment involving participants in several dozen focus groups, each with 3–10 Jewish Israeli participants, in Haifa, Israel. The topic of discussion for these focus groups centered on the killing of a neutralized Palestinian attacker by an Israeli soldier in March, 2016, and specifically addressed whether or not the soldier’s actions should have been condemned by prominent Israeli political and military leaders as it was. The experimental treatment was delivered through a confederate who participated in these groups as if he were also a research subject. In a third of the groups, the confederate took a neutral position; in the other two-thirds, he argued in favor of condemnation from either a moral or pragmatic frame. To measure the effect of these frames, after the focus group, participants provided measures of their willingness to engage in ingroup criticism themselves, their approval of criticism coming from other ingroup members, and their willingness to compromise with the outgroup (Palestinians). There was also a true control, where some participants who didn’t participate in any group answer the same outcome questions. It is hypothesized that results from this experiment will show that a moral frame causes people to become more critical of the soldier’s actions and more supportive of leaders’ criticism, but that the confederate will incur a backlash from other ingroup members who will rate him/her lower than other participants. Note that this design is based on a very similar experiment conducted in 2016. The results of that experiment were used to adjust the hypotheses for this study, in comparison to the 2016 design and PAP.

q16.value: Most of the quantities of interest fall into three groups in this study: (1) willingness to engage in ingroup criticism, (2) approval of criticism coming from other ingroup members, and (3) willingness to compromise with the outgroup (Palestinians). 1. Willingness to engage in ingroup criticism: - An index of responses to four statements about the behavior of the soldier (agree/disagree, 1-7 scale). - Coded participant statement in a letter asked to write (supportive/condemning of soldier, 1-5 scale). - Average of coded participant statements in focus group (supportive/condemning of soldier, 1-5 scale). 2. Approval of criticism coming from other ingroup members: - An index of responses to two statements about leaders' condemnation of soldier (agree/disagree, 1-7 scale). - Coded participant statement in a letter asked to write (supportive/condemning of leaders, 1-5 scale). - Responses to statements about how convincing other participants were and how much they contributed to the conversation – the average for other participants is subtracted from the ratings for the confederate, for a difference measure (note that this differs from the 2016 pre-analysis plan) - An index of responses to eleven statements about the importance of silencing others (agree/disagree, 1-7 scale). 3. Willingness to compromise with the outgroup (Palestinians): - Indices of responses to seven statements about willingness to compromise over a variety of issues in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict (oppose/support, 1-5 scale, two separate indices, one with the first five questions, the other with the final two). "Moral" treatment, compared to control: more willingness to engage in ingroup criticism, higher approval of criticism from others except for the confederate where there will be lower approval, and more willingness to compromise with Palestinians. "Pragmatic " treatment, compared to control: more willingness to engage in ingroup criticism, higher approval of criticism from others, and more willingness to compromise with Palestinians. Participants in the treatment groups will be compared both to the true control and to participants in the control focus groups. Lastly, I will analyze the transcripts of the focus groups using an STM. I hypothesize that participants mimic the language of the confederate. To bar against any potential for biased results, I will use the STM package in R with its search function to find the number of topics that best fit my texts. In the STM, I will include controls for each individual and how long into the focus group each individual made their statements.

q17.value: These hypotheses will be tested using linear regression. Because of the small sample size, I will control for some important covariates that are likely to have an effect on the outcome, aside from a regression without such covariates. Importantly, I will not include any such covariates to control for imbalances between treatment and control groups. Covariates to control for when looking at outcomes measuring willingness to engage in ingroup criticism: An index of responses to four statements measuring subjects' level of identification as Jewish and political ideology. Covariates to control for when looking at outcomes measuring approval of criticism coming from other ingroup members: An index of responses to four statements measuring subjects' level of identification as Jewish and political ideology. Covariates to control for when looking at outcomes measuring willingness to compromise with the outgroup (Palestinians): An index of responses to four statements measuring subjects' level of identification as Jewish, political ideology, and a dichotomous variable for whether or not the subject has been exposed to violence related to the conflict (as measured by responses to three questions). Note that I will not use clustered standard errors in my analysis. In the 2016 study, I specified that I would be the “randomization occurred at the focus group level.” While this is the case, participants in the 2016 study (and this study) are also randomly assigned to treatment conditions before being assigned to a focus group. Thus, participants treatment assignments are not correlated within clusters, either in this study or the 2016 study. For this reason, it is not appropriate to use clustered standard errors in my analysis. See Abadie et al, 2017, “When Should You Adjust Standard Errors for Clustering?”

Covariates to control for when looking at outcomes measuring willingness to compromise with the outgroup (Palestinians): An index of responses to four statements measuring subjects' level of identification as Jewish, political ideology, and a dichotomous variable for whether or not the subject has been exposed to violence related to the conflict (as measured by responses to three questions). Note that I will not use clustered standard errors in my analysis. In the 2016 study, I specified that I would be the “randomization occurred at the focus group level.” While this is the case, participants in the 2016 study (and this study) are also randomly assigned to treatment conditions before being assigned to a focus group. Thus, participants treatment assignments are not correlated within clusters, either in this study or the 2016 study. For this reason, it is not appropriate to use clustered standard errors in my analysis. See Abadie et al, 2017, “When Should You Adjust Standard Errors for Clustering?”

attributes.title: Still One Drop of Blood? The New Rules of Racial Classification in the U.S.

q1.value: Still One Drop of Blood? The New Rules of Racial Classification in the U.S.

q2.value: Ariela Schachter | René Flores | Neda Maghbouleh

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: U.S. racial boundaries, rooted in African slavery, have long been characterized as rigid. For most of U.S. history, ancestry has determined who is classified as either “black” or “white.” The hypodescent rule, which was codified into law, stipulated that a single drop of African blood made a person “black” (Davis 1991). However, some scholars argue that the rules of racial classification are now in flux (Alba; Gans 2012). The post-1965 immigration waves, originating mostly from Asia and Latin America, have complicated the old U.S. white/black racial binary. These new immigrants often do not neatly fit into either white or black categories. Further, their offspring often marry native whites giving rise to a growing multiracial population. Scholars are unsure how multiracials will come to be classified by the white majority and/or whether the hypodescent rule will apply to them (Lee and Bean 2004). Some claim that their descendants will be accepted as “white” particularly if they are light skinned and middle class. However, others envision a different future, in which some Latinos and Asians continue to be racialized as “non- white” (Bonilla-Silva 2004). In addition, there is growing sociological evidence that non- biological social factors can shape perceived race such as one’s romantic partners (Flores 2018), class background (Freeman et al. 2011), and even criminal record (Saperstein and Penner 2010). This evidence suggests that the rules of racial classification may be becoming more flexible, moving away from ancestry as the sole race criterion. In this survey experiment, we seek to uncover the current rules of racial classification in the U.S. by exploring the role that biological factors like ancestry and skin color play in shaping perceived race. In addition, we will assess the relative weight of non-biological social and cultural factors such as language, class background, and religion in shaping racial classification. Given that perceived racial status continues to shape people’s lives (Pager 2008), it is crucial to understand the rules that govern racial classification in the U.S. today. This experiment will contribute to key theoretical debates in sociological research on racial classification, ancestry, and group boundaries.

q16.value: In this survey experiment, we will examine the effect of biological, social, and cultural factors in shaping perceived race in the U.S. Our independent variables are: religion, skin color, occupation, name, primary language spoken at home, and genetic ancestry test results. These attributes were selected based on their importance in shaping perceptions of race (Bonilla-Silva 2004; Freeman et al. 2011; Garcia and Abascal 2016). Following a proposed Census 2020 ethnic identification question, our respondents will be able to classify each profile in one of six different racial/ethnic groups: white, black, Hispanic, Asian/Pacific Islander, Native American, and Middle Eastern/North African. These will be our dependent variables. Based on prior literature, we hypothesize that biological markers like skin color and ancestry test results will be especially impactful for “white” and “black” categories. We expect that lighter skin tones and European ancestry will result in higher probabilities of being classified as “white.” In contrast, we expect darker skin tones and African ancestry to increase the odds of “black” classification. In contrast, we expect that cultural and social markers will be especially important for the other ethnoracial groups. We expect that the probabilities of “Latino” classification will significantly increase when profiles signal Catholic religion, Spanish language, and typical Spanish names. Similarly, we expect that Asian names and languages will significantly increase classification as “Asian.” We do not expect a strong effect for religion in the case of Asians given the diversity of Asians’ religious affiliations (Ecklund and Park 2007). We expect religion to be a particularly important cue for MENA identification. We expect being Muslim, speaking Arabic, and having a Middle-Eastern name to significantly increase MENA classification. With regards to classification as Native-American, we also expect indigenous names along with speaking an indigenous language to be important factors. Based on prior literature, we expect occupational status, a strong marker of class background, to shape perceived race (Freeman et al. 2011). More specifically, given current ethnoracial inequalities in the U.S., we expect that a high occupational status will increase the odds of white and Asian classification. In turn, we expect a negative effect of occupational status on black, Latino, and Native American classifications. In addition, we will conduct several interaction tests. We will test whether these patterns vary by whether respondents have taken an ancestry test themselves. We will also test whether living in the U.S. South, an area known for particularly rigid racial boundaries, interacts with our subjects’ responses. Lastly, we will test whether skin color interacts with our other treatments. This will test whether and how physical signals of race—skin color—constrain or amplify the impact of other signals of race.

q17.value: To address these questions, we will use a paired conjoint survey experiment on a representative sample of 1,500 non-Hispanic adult U.S. residents. YouGov, an independent polling firm, will apply this experiment. In the experiment, respondents will compare the profiles of two individuals side by side that list a number of individual traits and classify their race. This allows us to test the independent effect of each dimension on perceived race net of all other attributes, as well as explore interactions among the attributes. The individual traits are: religion, skin color, occupation, name, primary language spoken at home, and genetic ancestry test results. We use a survey experiment because it lets us compare the effects of multiple immigrant attributes on public perceptions (Schachter 2016). Our conjoint design (Hainmueller, Hopkins, and Yamamoto 2014) allows us to create profiles of hypothetical individuals who vary along several cultural, social, and phenotypic dimensions. In the experiment respondents read a short passage, which introduces the task by saying, “We are interested in studying how people classify the race/ethnicity of others. You will be presented with pairs of profiles describing different individuals living in the United States. For each pair of profiles, please look at the information carefully, and then indicate how you would classify each person’s race/ethnicity. There are no correct or incorrect answers for this, we just want to understand how people make these classifications. Even if you aren’t entirely sure, please indicate your best guess about the race/ethnicity of each person” (see Design Appendix). They are then presented with two randomly assigned profiles and are asked, “How would you classify these individuals? (please chose the single best category for each individual)” Response options are: White, Black, Native American, Hispanic, Middle Eastern/North African (MENA), and Asian. Respondents separately assess each individual profile. We use responses to this question as the dependent variable in our main analysis. We will test these hypotheses by running separate OLS regression models predicting each racial category separately. Our treatments will be the predictor variables. Since our respondents are evaluating multiple profiles, we will adjust our standard errors for clustering at the respondent level.
